etymologies: early 18th century; earliest use found in Four Years Voyages of Captain G. Roberts. From cockbill

definitions: To move (an anchor) into the position of hanging vertically from the cathead with the bills pointing upwards, as when ready for dropping. Now chiefly historical.
To set (a yard) at an angle so that one end is higher than the other.

notes.text: The yards of vessels are sometimes angled in this way as a sign of mourning.

definitions: With reference to an anchor: in or into the position of hanging vertically from the cathead with the bills pointing upwards, as when ready for dropping; (also with reference to a yard) at an angle, with one end higher than the other.
